journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part O: Journal of Risk and Reliability

title-group.article-title: Competing failure analysis in non-repairable binary systems subject to functional dependence

article-meta.aff: 1Electrical and Computer Engineering Department, University of Massachusetts, Dartmouth, USA
2School of Computer Science, University of Electronic Science and Technology of China, China

author-notes.corresp: Liudong Xing, Electrical and Computer Engineering Department, University of Massachusetts, Dartmouth, 285 Old Westport Road, North Dartmouth, MA 02747, USA. Email: lxing@umassd.edu

abstract.p: This paper considers competing failure propagation and isolation effects in the reliability analysis of systems with functional dependence, where the failure of some trigger component causes other components (referred to as dependent components) to become inaccessible or isolated from the system. A propagated failure originating from a dependent component could affect other parts of the system and thus cause the entire system to fail. However, if the trigger component fails first, the propagation of the dependent component failure can be prevented and thus it cannot affect the function of the rest of the system. In other words, propagated failures originating from dependent components in systems with functional dependence can have different consequences due to their competition with the failure of the trigger component in the time domain. This paper suggests a combinatorial method to address such competing failure behavior in the reliability analysis of non-repairable binary-state systems. Different from the work reported in the literature that assumes local and propagated failures of a component being mutually exclusive, the proposed method is applicable to independent and dependent local and propagated component failures. The system reliability analysis results for all the three cases (mutually exclusive, independent and dependent) are compared through a case study. The proposed method is verified through comparison with Markov-based methods.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: As a type of common-cause failure, a propagated failure with global effect (PFGE) originating from a component within a subsystem/system can cause the failure of the entire subsystem/system.1 The PFGE has been studied intensively in the literature.2–6 The two main causes for the occurrence of a PFGE can be summarized as follows.

list-item.p: Imperfect fault coverage. Despite the presence of adequate redundancy and fault-tolerant mechanism, a component fault, if it is not detected or located successfully, can propagate throughout the system and cause the failure of the entire system.

Destructive effect of failures originating from some system components on other components. Some types of failures can cause fire, overheating, short-circuit, blackout, explosion, etc., which destroys or incapacitates all other components of the system.

sec.p: However, it is not always the case that the PFGE causes an overall system failure. In particular, in systems subject to functional dependence behavior, the occurrence of a trigger event causes other components (referred to as dependent components) to become inaccessible or isolated from the system (i.e. failure isolation effect). The propagation of a failure originating from a dependent component can thus be prevented and cannot affect other parts of the system if the trigger event occurs before the propagated failure of the dependent component occurs. For example, consider a computer network where communication among computers is achieved through network interface cards (NICs). In this case, each NIC is a trigger component and corresponding connected computers are dependent components. The failure of the card not only makes the computers connected to the network through this card inaccessible in the network, but also makes the network insensitive to any failure originating from these computers.7,8 For another example, consider a set of peripheral devices (such as keyboards, monitors, printers, webcams) accessed through input/output (I/O) controllers in a computer system. The failure of the I/O controller not only makes the connected peripheral devices unusable, but also makes the computer system insensitive to any failure of those peripheral devices.9 In this case, peripheral devices are functionally dependent on the I/O controller. Such a functional dependence relationship and failure isolation effect can also be found in hierarchical clustered sensor networks, where sensor nodes within a cluster can be accessed through a cluster head.10 If the cluster head fails, all the sensor nodes in that cluster will be isolated from the rest of the network. Note that the failure isolation takes effect only when the trigger component (e.g. the NIC in the first example) fails before any PFGE occurs in the dependent components. If the propagated failure (for example, some computer virus) originating from a dependent computer occurs before the NIC failure, the whole network could crash as the virus spreads itself throughout the network.

In summary, there are two distinct consequences of a PFGE due to the competition in the time domain between the trigger failure and the propagated failure originating from a dependent component (or in other words, between the failure isolation and failure propagation effects). Such competition failure processes must be addressed for the accurate system analysis. Recently Xing and Levitin11 proposed a combinatorial method for the reliability analysis of systems subject to competing failures. This method assumes that the local failure and propagated failure of the same component are mutually exclusive (or disjoint), meaning the occurrence of a local failure prevents the occurrence of the propagated failure, and vice versa. In practice, however, the two types of failures may be s-independent. For example, a computer may experience a local failure due to a hard disk failure and a propagated failure due to some computer virus. The virus can propagate without using the hard disk; on the other hand the hard disk failure prevents task executions independently from the virus activity. Both failures can occur simultaneously and independently. Moreover, the two types of failures can also be s-dependent. For example, the local hard disk failure of a computer can increase the possibility of a propagated failure caused by a virus because the anti-virus software installed on the hard disk fails to function in the case of the hard disk failure, which makes the computer easier to be affected by some virus. The method suggested in Xing and Levitin11 cannot be directly applied to handle s-independent or s-dependent local and propagated failures.

Competing failures have been studied in the literature and models for evaluating the reliability of systems suffering from multiple kinds of competing failure causes have been developed.12–14 Maintained systems with multiple competing failure processes have also been studied.15–18 The problems associated with achieving optimal system size for systems with competing failure modes19–21 and accelerated life tests in the presence of competing failure causes22–25 have also been discussed in the literature. However, the competing failures addressed in those works were mainly referred to as competition among multiple types of failure modes; they are different from those studied in this paper where the competition exists between the failure isolation and failure propagation effects in the time domain. Therefore, the methods presented in those works are not applicable to the competing failure analysis considered in this work.

In this paper, the combinatorial method presented in Xing and Levitin11 is adapted for the reliability analysis of non-repairable binary-state systems subject to competing failures and independent or dependent local and propagated failures. The system reliability analysis results for the cases of independent and dependent failures are compared to those for mutually exclusive failures obtained in Xing and Levitin11 for a case study. The method is verified through comparison with Markov-based method. Similar to the method of Xing and Levitin11 the adapted method is applicable to cases where the effects of failures of the trigger components on the corresponding dependent components are independent so that the groups of components affected by the propagated failures can be analyzed separately. This condition always holds when the system contains a single trigger component.

The remainder of the paper is organized as follows. The section “Propagated failure method″ presents a preliminary method for handling propagated failures in the system reliability analysis. The section “Combinatorial competing failure analysis method″ presents the adapted combinatorial approach for the reliability analysis of binary-state systems subject to competing failures and independent or dependent local and propagated failures. The section “Illustrative example and analysis″ gives an illustrative example and the analysis of the example system for both independent and dependent cases. In the section “Verification and discussion″ the correctness of the method is verified by comparison with results obtained using the Markov method and reliability results for three cases of independent, dependent and mutually exclusive local and propagated failures are compared. Finally, conclusions and directions for future work are presented in the section “Conclusions and future work.”

sec.title: Propagated failure method
sec.p: This section presents a separable method for handling propagated failures in general system reliability analysis. The method is referred to as the propagated failure method (PFM) hereinafter.

The failure of a component can be local or propagated. A local failure causes only outage of the component from which the failure is originated; whereas a propagated failure causes extensive damage to the system. If a propagated failure originating from any component of a subsystem/system causes the entire subsystem/system to fail, a PFGE has occurred; if the propagated failures originating from different components cause failures of different (possibly overlapping) subsets of system components, a propagated failure with selective effect (PFSE) has occurred. Refer to Levitin and Xing1 for a study of PFSE in system reliability analysis. This work is focused only on local failures and PFGE for the system components, and it is assumed that they are two statistical processes modeled by two random variables Til and Tip, respectively. fil(t) and fip(t) represent the probability density function (PDF) of Til and Tip for a system component i, respectively. Let qil(t) (qip(t)) be the unconditional local (propagated) failure probability for component i at time t. Thus,

In the case when the local and propagated failures are s-dependent, qip(t) is evaluated using the total probability law as

Q(t) in equation (1) is a conditional system failure probability given that no propagated failures have occurred. It can be evaluated using any approach ignoring propagated failures such as binary decision diagram (BDD)-based methods.4,7 However, for evaluating Q(t), it is necessary to use a conditional component failure probability qi(t) given no propagated failure occurring in the component. When the local failure and propagated failure are s-independent, the conditional component failure probability is computed using
When the local failure and propagated failure are s-dependent, the conditional component failure probability is computed using
Note that equations (4) and (5) differ from the equation for qi(t) in Xing and Levitin11 where the local and propagated failures of the same component are assumed to be mutually exclusive.

sec.title: Combinatorial competing failure analysis method
sec.p: This section describes the general methodology for the reliability analysis of non-repairable binary-state system subjected to competing failures and independent or dependent local and propagated failures. In the next section the method is illustrated using a case study and in the section after that the method is verified using the Markov method. The method involves the following three steps.

Step 1: Define three distinct events (Ri) that represent different failure orders of the trigger component and its corresponding dependent components; evaluate the occurrence probabilities of these events.
R1 = “the trigger component does not fail locally.” Assume that the unconditional local failure event of the trigger component A is YAl. Pr(R1) is calculated as

Note that in the case of the trigger component being subject to propagated failure in addition to local failure, PFM should be applied to separate the propagation effect originating from the trigger component before step 1. Also, qAl(t) in equation (6) should be replaced with qA(t) calculated using equation (4) when the local and propagated failures of the trigger component are independent, or qA(t) calculated using equation (5) when the local and propagated failures are dependent. In addition, the PDF of the time-to-local failure of trigger component A used in equation (10), i.e. fAl(τ2) should be evaluated as dqA(t)/dt accordingly.

R 2 = “at least one dependent component fails globally before the occurrence of the trigger local failure event.” Assume there are n dependent components D1, D2, …, Dn for the trigger component A and the propagated failure events of those dependent components are, respectively YD1p, YD2p, …, and YDnp. Then Pr(R2) is evaluated as

where

In general, the probability of sequential failures of n components can be obtained by
where X1, …, Xn are random variables representing the time-to-failure of those n components.
Applying equation (9), equation (7) can be evaluated as
where
Note that one can evaluate reliability of a system without propagated failures from dependent components using the proposed method with Pr(R2) = 0.

R 3 = “the trigger component fails locally before any propagated failure originating from the dependent components occurs.” Since the three events form a complete event space, Pr(R3) can be simply calculated as: Pr(R3) = 1−Pr(R1)−Pr(R2).
Step 2: Evaluate the conditional probabilities of system failure given the occurrence of Ri, that is, Pr(system fails | Ri), where i∈{1,2,3}.
Pr(system fails | R1) is evaluated by applying the PFM approach to the system reliability model after the removal of trigger failure events.
Pr(system fails | R2) is always equal to one because when at least one dependent component causes PFGE and when there is no failure isolation, the system fails.

Pr(system fails | R3) is evaluated based on a reduced fault tree. When R3 happens, the failure isolation effect always takes place. Therefore, events in the system fault tree model representing the failure of the trigger component and the corresponding dependent components are replaced with constant “1” (TRUE). A Boolean reduction (using rules of 1+x = 1 and 1 x x = x, where x represents a Boolean variable) is then applied to generate the reduced fault tree model for evaluating Pr(system fails | R3).
Step 3: Compute the unreliability of the entire system based on the total probability theorem26 as

Note that as mentioned at the end of the Introduction, the above three-step method is general and applicable to systems with one functional dependence group (i.e. trigger–dependent component propagated failures group), or multiple independent and non-overlapped functional dependence groups. In the case of systems subjected to multiple dependent or overlapped functional dependence groups, the method can be extended by expanding the event space in step 1 to consider all possible orders of the dependent trigger components failures and related propagated failures. Such an extension will be investigated in future work. A Markov model is a potential method that can address the problem, but it suffers from the well-known state space explosion problem when analyzing large systems. Moreover, the Markov method can only be applied to systems with components with an exponential time-to-failure distribution. The proposed method, however, is applicable to any arbitrary time-to-failure distributions for the system components.

sec.title: Illustrative example and analysis
sec.p: In this section a case study is used to illustrate the application of the proposed methodology for the reliability analysis of binary-state systems subject to competing PFGE and failure isolation effects. The first subsection describes the example system. The second subsection gives the detailed analysis of the example system for the case where the local and propagated failures of the same component are independent. The third subsection gives the analysis for the case where the local and propagated failures are dependent.

sec.title: System description
sec.p: Figure 1 illustrates a computer system with a memory subsystem that is subjected to competing PFGE and failure isolation effects. The memory subsystem consists of an independent memory module (MM), and two memory chips (MC1 and MC2) that are accessed by CPU through a memory interface unit (MIU). In other words, the two memory chips are functionally dependent on the MIU. The memory subsystem is working if both memory chips are functioning or the standalone memory module is functioning. For simplifying the notation in the example analysis, A, B, C, D are used to respectively represent MIU, MC1, MC2 and MM in the later discussions.

caption.p: Structure diagram of an example system.

sec.p: Figure 2 shows the fault tree model of the example system, where the functional dependence (FDEP) gate is used to model the functional dependence between components {B, C} and A; A is a trigger component whereas both B and C are dependent components which are functionally dependent on A. All the four components can experience local failures. Only B and C can cause the PFGE.

caption.p: Fault tree model of the example system.11

sec.p:
The previously described combinatorial method is applicable to the reliability analysis of systems with components having any arbitrary type of time-to-failure distributions. However, the Markov method can only be used for systems with exponentially distributed components. To compare the results obtained using both methods and thus verify the correctness of the proposed method, it is assumed that both time-to-local failures and time-to-propagated failures of all components to be exponentially distributed for this example. Let λAl, λBl, λCl and λDl be the local failure rates of components A, B, C and D, respectively. Let λBp and λCp be the unconditional propagated failure rates of components B and C, respectively. In the case of local and propagated failures being dependent, conditional failure rates are given to model the dependence. In particular,

sec.title: Independent local and propagated failures
sec.p: Assume the local and propagated failures of the same component to be s-independent. Assume that the unconditional failure rates of the system components are λAl = 0.0001/h, λBl = λCl = 0.0002/h, λBp = λCp = 0.000,01/h and λDl = 0.0002/h. The steps for analyzing the example memory system of the previous subsection are as follows.
Step 1: Define three distinct events (Ri) and evaluate their occurrence probabilities.
R 1: the trigger component A does not fail locally. Since A’s local failure follows the exponential distribution, according to equation (6)
R 2: at least one dependent component (Bp OR Cp) fails globally before the local failure of the trigger component A. The occurrence probability of R2 is
According to equation (8), Pr(YBp∪YCp) can be calculated as

Step 2: Evaluate the conditional probabilities of system failure given the occurrence of Ri.

Pr(system fails|R1): when R1 happens, that is when the trigger component A is functioning, there is no failure isolation effect. Pr(system fails|R1) can be evaluated by applying the PFM approach to the system reliability model after the removal of the trigger event, which is shown in Figure 3 for this example.

caption.p: Reduced fault tree for Pr(system fails|R1).

sec.p: Applying equation (1), Pr(system fails|R1) can be obtained as
According to equation (2), Pu(t) in equation (22) can be obtained as

Q(t) in equation (22) can be evaluated by solving the reduced fault tree while ignoring all propagated failures. To evaluate Q(t), conditional component failure probabilities are used. According to equation (4)
The BDD model11 for evaluating the reduced fault tree in Figure 3 is shown in Figure 4. There are two paths for the root to the sink node “1”: D→B→“1” and D→B→C→“1.”
Q(t) can be obtained as the sum of probabilities of those two paths using conditional component failure probabilities as follows
According to equations (1), (23) and (25), the system failure probability given the occurrence of R1 is

Pr(system fails|R2): when at least one dependent component (Bp OR Cp) fails globally before the failure of the trigger component A, there is no failure isolation and the system fails. Therefore, the system failure probability given the occurrence of R2 is

Pr(system fails|R3): when the trigger component A fails before any propagated failure originating from the dependent components, the isolation effect takes place. Thus, propagated failures from both B and C are isolated by the failure of the trigger A so that they do not cause a global effect on the entire system. After applying the discussed reduction procedure, the reduced fault tree model for the case R3 can be obtained as shown in Figure 5.

caption.p: Reduced fault tree for Pr(system fails|R3).

sec.p: According to Figure 5, the system failure probability given the occurrence of R3 is simply

Step 3: According to equation (12), the unreliability of the example memory system with component local and propagated failures being s-independent can be obtained by integrating equations (15), (20), (21) and (26) to (28)

Using the values of λAl = 0.0001/h, λBl = λCl = λDl = 0.0002/h and λBp = λCp = 0.000,01/h, the unreliability of the example memory subsystem is obtained as 0.0306, 0.0889, 0.6128 and 0.8757 for mission times of 500, 1000, 5000 and 10,000 h, respectively.

sec.title: Verification and discussion
sec.p: For verification of the correctness of the proposed method, the example memory system in Figure 2 for the case of independent local and propagated failures is analyzed using the Markov method and results obtained using both methods are compared.

Figure 6 shows the compact state transition diagram in the Markov model of the example memory system. Note that since for B and C, propagated failure and local failure are two independent processes, B is separated into Bp and Bl, C into Cp and Cl. The definition of each state is given as follows:
state 0: no failed components in the system;
state 1: D fails (locally), the rest of the components work;
state 2: A fails first, D does not fail, and B and C do not fail globally (causing propagated failure);
state 3: either B or C fails (locally), the rest of the components work;
state 4: the system fails.

caption.p: State transition diagram for the example system.

sec.p: The solution to the above constructed Markov model gives the probability of each state as
Thus, the unreliability of the example system using the Markov method is

The expression obtained in equation (45) matches exactly the one obtained in equation (29), which verifies the correctness of the proposed combinatorial method. Again, it is worth pointing out that the Markov method is limited to the exponential time-to-failure distribution, and cannot handle the s-dependent relationship between local and propagated failures; whereas the proposed method has no limitation on the type of distributions for the system components and can handle both independent and dependent local and propagated failures, as illustrated in the sections “Independent local and propagated failures″ and “Dependent local and propagated failures″, respectively.

In addition, the Markov method suffers from the state space explosion problem. As the number of system components increases, the rapid growth of the number of states often leads to models that are computationally intensive and intractable. For example, consider a large fault-tolerant memory system in Figure 7(a), which is actually an expanded version of the memory system in Figure 1. This memory system consists of 10 memory chips, which are functionally dependent on the MIU and can experience both local and propagated failures. The memory system fails when at least seven out of the 10 memory chips and the standalone memory module have failed, as illustrated by the fault tree model in Figure 7(b). The Markov model of this system consists of 355 states. This implies that a set of 355 differential equations must be solved for the system reliability analysis, which is computationally intractable. However, similar to the analysis of the example system in the section “Illustrative example and analysis″, reliability of such large system can be efficiently obtained using the proposed three-step method, where Pr(system fails|R1) can be computed using the PFM and BDD methods, Pr(system fails|R2) = 1, and Pr(system fails|R3) = Pr(YL).

caption.p: An example of a large system: (a) structure diagram, and (b) fault tree model.

sec.p: Using the same set of parameters as in the section “Independent local and propagated failures″ (i.e. λAl = 0.0001/h, λBl = λCl = 0.0002/h, λBp = λCp = 0.000,01/h and λDl = 0.0002/h), Xing and Levitin11 analyzed the same example system of Figure 2 but assuming that the local and propagated component failures were mutually exclusive. For comparison purpose, the numerical results for the unreliability of the example system for the three cases are tabulated in Table 1: s-independent (“Independent local and propagated failures″), s-dependent (“Dependent local and propagated failures″), and mutually exclusive.11

caption.p: Summary of analysis results for the example system.

sec.p: It can be seen that in the case where local and propagated component failures are independent, the system unreliability is lower than that for the case where the two types of failures are mutually exclusive. Indeed in the independent case the probability that both types of failures occur simultaneously is non-zero, unlike the mutually exclusive case where both types of failures can never occur simultaneously. However, for the same component parameter values, the reliability of the component in the independent case is higher than the component reliability in the mutually exclusive case. The reason for this behavior is that in the independent case, the reliability of the component, i.e. the probability that the component does not experience local or propagated failure is calculated as [1 - qil(t)] × [1 - qip(t)]; whereas in the mutually exclusive case, the component reliability is calculated as [1 - qil(t) - qip(t)], which is less than [1 - qil(t)] × [1 - qip(t)]. Thus, the overall system unreliability evaluated based on component reliabilities in the independent case is lower than the system unreliability in the mutually exclusive case.

It is intuitive that the system unreliability in the dependent case is higher than that in the independent or mutually exclusive case because the occurrence of component local failure leads to an increased likelihood of the propagated failure, i.e. the positive dependence27 is assumed for the example input parameters.

sec.title: Conclusions and future work
sec.p: This paper presented an analytical and combinatorial method for the reliability analysis of non-repairable binary-state systems subjected to competing failure propagation and isolation effects. Both s-independent and s-dependent local and propagated component failures were considered. The proposed method has no limitation on the time-to-failure distributions for the system components or limitation on the system structures. The method was verified through the comparison to the Markov method on the analysis of an example system. In future work, more complicated cases of propagated failures with mixed selective and global effects, and cases where systems have multiple functional dependence groups with shared dependent components will be investigated. Solutions to address the competing failure processes in repairable systems and dynamic systems with multi-state,28,29 multi-phase4 and/or dynamic sparing behavior 5,30 will be investigated.
